cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center.

planeCategories.name: Material Realm
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

timeFlow.description: Time flows normally on the Material Plane. Creatures require food and water daily based on their size.

hazards.name: Malnutrition
hazards.description: A creature requires a minimum amount of food each day based on its size (Tiny: 1/4 pound, Small: 1 pound, Medium: 1 pound, Large: 4 pounds, Huge: 16 pounds, Gargantuan: 64 pounds). A creature that eats but consumes less than half the required food must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw at the end of the day or gain 1 Exhaustion level. A creature that eats nothing automatically gains 1 Exhaustion level at the end of the day with no saving throw allowed.

savingThrowToTraverse.triggerDescription: At the end of each day when the creature eats but consumes less than half the required food for its size. A creature that eats nothing automatically fails (no save allowed).

onFailure.description: The creature gains 1 Exhaustion level. Exhaustion is cumulative; each failed save adds 1 level. At 6 Exhaustion levels, the creature dies. Each Exhaustion level reduces all D20 Tests by 2 times the Exhaustion level and reduces Speed by 5 times the Exhaustion level. Finishing a Long Rest removes 1 Exhaustion level.
onFailure.duration: Until removed by finishing a Long Rest (removes 1 level per Long Rest)
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each day without sufficient food can add 1 Exhaustion level. At 6 Exhaustion levels, the creature dies.

onSuccess.description: The creature suffers no ill effects from insufficient food for that day.

recoveryMethods: Eating sufficient food for the creature's size and finishing a Long Rest to remove 1 Exhaustion level per Long Rest

hazards.sourceReference: Appendix C: Rules Glossary (Food entry), Chapter 1: Playing the Game (Hazards section)

specialRules.name: Daily Food Requirements by Creature Size
specialRules.description: Each creature requires a daily amount of food based on its size: Tiny requires 1/4 pound, Small requires 1 pound, Medium requires 1 pound, Large requires 4 pounds, Huge requires 16 pounds, and Gargantuan requires 64 pounds. Eating less than half the required amount triggers a DC 15 Constitution saving throw at the end of the day. Eating nothing results in automatic gain of 1 Exhaustion level with no saving throw.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Eating less than half required food: DC 15 Constitution saving throw at end of day or gain 1 Exhaustion level. Eating nothing: automatically gain 1 Exhaustion level at end of day (no save). Exhaustion is cumulative. Each level reduces D20 Tests by 2 times the level and Speed by 5 times the level in feet. Death occurs at 6 Exhaustion levels. A Long Rest removes 1 Exhaustion level.

crossReferences.description: Chapter 1: Playing the Game lists Malnutrition as a hazard defined in the rules glossary. Appendix C: Rules Glossary defines the Food entry with malnutrition mechanics and the Water/Food Needs per Day table.

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
